free_txt: BL
M.M. Misprints in reference were corrected:
Free text was corrected to be human-readable.
Dates were corrected for 4-digits year .
BIB information was added.
SD: STATUS updated in Subents 002,003.
STATUS deelted from Subent 001 (Both 002 and 003 are
superseded by 22109.

bib_record.title: S-wave neutron strength function of Ta-181

free_txt: I.Tsubone, Y.Nakajima
Y.Kanda
Electron Linear Accelerator, operated
with 120MeV electron energy, 300pps of repetition rate,
30 ns electron burst width, 20-30 microA average beam
current.
Resonance energies and neutron widths were
determined for 632 levels from 100 to 3720 eV by shape
analysis of transmission data using least squares shape
analysis code SIOB, based on multi-level Breit-Wigner
formula taking into account Doppler and resolution
broadenings. Capture width was assumed 55 millieV for
all levels - from BNL-325 3rd edition. Statistical
spin factors also from BNL-325, if available,
otherwise 0.5 was assumed.
Resonance parameters below 100 eV were employed from
BNL-325 3rd edition.
Average level spacing and s-wave neutron strength
function were deduced from these values.
For counting loses by the dead time and subtraction of
the background - before transmission deducing.
Li-6 glass scintillator of 11.1 cm diameter,
0.635 cm thick as neutron detector for low resolution.
Detector located at 190m consisted of 5 sets of Li-6
glass scintillators of 11.1 cm diameter, 1.25 cm thick
each. Neutron intensity was monitored by two Li-6
glass detectors at 45 and 100 m stations.
Electron Linear Accelerator, operated
with 120MeV electron energy, 300pps of repetition rate,
30 ns electron burst width, 20-30 microA average beam
current.
Water cooled tantalum target .
Neutrons were moderated by boron-loaded polyethylene
disk of 20 cm diameter, 5 cm thick. 30 cm thick lead
shadow rings to reduce gamma-flash signals in detector.
Neutron beam was made passed through 5 mm thick boron
nitride or 6 mm thick Boral plate to remove time
overlap neutrons for low and high resolution
measurement, respectively.
Flight path lengths of 56.34 m (low resolution)
and 191.52 m (high resolution).
For background estimation: metallic Na was used at low
resolution measurement, in high resolution experiment
the transmission of 15 mm thick U plate was measured.
Black resonances of Ta-181 were also used for
background estimation.
Neutron resonance spectroscopy was performed by
neutron transmission measurement.
Exp. details of
transmission measurements.
Code SIOB.
Vol.1. 3rd edition.
Natural Ta metallic plates. Ta-181 abundance 99.988 %.
Contribution of Ta-180 was ignored.
Two samples of thickness 0.00565 and 0.0560 at/b -
for low resolution measurement.
Three samples of 0.0112, 0.0280, 0.0560 at/b - for
high resolution measurement.
S-wave neutron strength function was obtained from
slope of plot of sum(g*WIDn0) vs neutron energy,
Fig.2 of Nucl.Sci.Tech.20(1983)707.
Error was estimated from conventional
statistical assumption deltaS0/S0 = (2/N)**0.5, where
N is number of levels.
Statistical fluctuation of resonance levels
is included .
text on p.709 from Nucl.Sci.Tech.20(1983)707
Average level spacing was obtained by the slope of the
plot of cumulative level count up to 1700 eV , see
Fig. 1 of Nucl.Sci.Tech.20(1983)707.
text on p.709 from Nucl.Sci.Tech.20(1983)707
